commitResults.messageTitle: MayoBot.java: Add skeletal greeting functionality
commitResults.messageBody:
Chatbot only prints out a "hello" message along with a logo.

No functionality is implemented, and the Duke project is not differentiated from the template.

Implementing the basic skeletal functionality where the bot simple greets the user and exits is the first step to the breadth-first development approach for this project. Also, renaming it will allow for differentiation and adding personal touch.

Let's add basic functionality to the project where the bot introduces its name, greets the user, and exits. Let's also rename Duke to MayoBot to add personalization.

commitResults.messageTitle: MayoBot.java: Add echo command functionality
commitResults.messageBody:
The skeletal version of the bot only greets the user and exits upon being run.

Let's improve the skeletal version of the project so that it echos commands entered by the user, and exits when the user types the command `bye`.

commitResults.messageTitle: MayoBot.java: Add ability to store and display input text
commitResults.messageBody:
The bot only repeats user input when entered, and only has the implementation of the exit command "bye".

Need to have some sort of memory of user input and begin implementing more commands for user to interact with the bot.

Let's add the ability for the bot to store whatever the user inputs, and implement the "list" command for the user to list out stored text.

Using a new TaskList for abstracting operations with regards to storing input text is preferable to maintain OOP principles and simplify implementation.

commitResults.messageTitle: Task related classes: Add classes for Task and TaskList
commitResults.messageBody:
Tasks are managed in the Task private static class within the main MayoBot class.

As the project expands, it would be preferable to manage Task and lists of Tasks separately in their own classes.

Let's add new class files Task.java and TaskList.java to manage these data objects and add corresponding operations to help with managing the code and commands of the main MayoBot chatbot.

Using separate classes is preferable to maintain OOP principles in the project.

commitResults.messageTitle: MayoBot.java: Add ability to mark Tasks and done/not done
commitResults.messageBody:
We can add input items to the bot and keep track of them, but no other operations on each item is possible. The main MayoBot class also does not implement the newly added task and TaskList classes.

We need to extend the functionality of the bot and add the ability for users to add and keep track of pending tasks.

Let's add the ability to mark tasks as done, and also add the ability to change the status back to "not done" by implementing the Task and TaskList classes.

Interfacing through the class abstraction barrier for Task and TaskList allows us to maintain OOP rpinciples in the project.

commitResults.messageTitle: MayoBot.java and Task classes: Add support for tracking three types of tasks with improved tokenization
commitResults.messageBody:
The bot only supports adding, marking, and unmarking a generic Task type with a command-switching system that is edious and does not support multiple arguments.

Extending the functionality of the bot to support multiple Task types is preferable. In order to support more commands to add different types of tasks (commands with arguments), an improved command tokenization system is necessary.

Let's add new classes for three Task types: Todo, Deadline, and Event, while turning the generic Task class into an abstract class. Let us also implement an improved command tokenization and switching system.

Turning the generic Task class into an abstract class supports inheritance (as teach task type will inherit the common functions and attributes). The improved tokenization system implemented using String splitting allows for arguments in commands. The command-switching system has also been abstracted into a private static method for enhanced logic and readability.

commitResults.messageTitle: text-ui-test: Add tests using I/O redirection technique
commitResults.messageBody:
The project has files and a script for automated text UI testing, but the input file is empty. The EXPECTED.txt file does not reflect expected outputs after recent iterations to the project.

In order to flesh out the project and ensure consistency and reliability in future iteration, testing needs to be implemented.

Let's implement the input.output redirection technique to semi-automate the testing of MayoBot, by adding input commands to input.txt, and adding the exected output in EXPECTED.txt.

commitResults.messageTitle: MayoBot.java and exception classes: Add exception handling
commitResults.messageBody:
The chatbot does not support exception handling for incorrect command formats.

Entering an existing command in an incorrect format leads to fatal errors and the program crashing.

Let's create the generic MayoBotException class and separate exception classes for all implemented commands with arguments, to allow graceful exception/error handling.

commitResults.messageTitle: Task classes: Refactor names to [Task type]Task.java
MayoBot.java and Task-related classes: Add delete task functionality
commitResults.messageBody:
Deletion of tasks is not supported by the chatbot.

Implementing deletion of tasks xtends the functionality of the bot.

Let's add support for deleting tasks from the list with the "delete" command, while also implementing its respective exception.

Alongside adding functionality for the "delete" command and its corresponding exception DeleteException, some refactoring of MayoBot.java and TaskList.java is needed to comply with OOP principles and encapsulation.

commitResults.messageTitle: MayoBot: Add Parser and Command classes
commitResults.messageBody:
The command parsing and execution logic is within the main MayoBot.java file.

In accordance with OOP principles, it would be more approrpiate to split and organize this logic into its own separate classes.

Let's create a Parser class that parses user command input, and creates a Command object. Let's transfer the runCommand() method in the main file to a statis method in the newly-created Command class.

commitResults.messageTitle: Storage: Add Storage class to save tasks
commitResults.messageBody:
The chatbot handles lists of tasks, but lists get erased every time the program is terminated.

Persistent storage of tasks saved in the list is needed to improve utility of the chatbot.

Let's begin to integrate the saving feature by adding a new Storage class to manage stored lists (in a .txt file) and support basic loading and saving operations.

commitResults.messageTitle: Storage and TaskList: Fix saved tasks
commitResults.messageBody:
When the chatbot saves tasks to user's local save file, it overwrites existing tasks instead of appending the new task to the saved list.

This causes issues with the list saving system.

Let's fix this bug by adding the 'true' argument to the FileWriter object in the Storage's saveTask() method. Accordingly, let's implement bug fixes to TaskList's use of the Storage class.

commitResults.messageTitle: Storage: Implement task marked/unmarked changes
commitResults.messageBody:
The user is unable to save marked/unmarked task as done/not done in the local data file.

This limits the functionality of the task list saving feature, as user is not able to manipulate task entry after saving.

Let's allow the user to mark/unmark saved tasks by triggering updation of the saved tasks after the status of a task has been updated.

commitResults.messageTitle: Storage: Allow task deletion to be saved
commitResults.messageBody:
Any task deletion is not reflected in the user's local save data.

This limits the implementation of the task list saving feature, as it should be able to reflect all changes/manipulations made to the list.

Let's allow task deletions to be reflected in the save data, by triggering saveTasks() method whenever a task is deleted.

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge branch 'branch-Level-7'
commitResults.messageBody:
The chatbot does not support saving of task lists on the user's local device, thus all tasks lists created are deleted every time the chatbot is close.

This limits the use and practicality of the chatbot's features.

Let's implement the save task lists feature developed in the 'branch-Level-7' branch by merging it to the 'master' branch.

commitResults.messageTitle: Task classes: Add date/time handling
commitResults.messageBody:
The chatbot does not understand dates and times for Deadline and Event task entries, as it just takes in String inputs for the by, from, and to fields.

Implementing date/time handling can allow for future operations with tasks and further extensions of the bot's functionalities.

Let's implement support for entered date/time entries for tasks by implementing java.time.LocalDateTime in task objects. Let's also update Parser to be able to parse date/time inputs and raise errors if input is incorrect.

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge branch 'branch-Level-8'
commitResults.messageBody:
MayoBot does not support handling of dates and times for task objects, as it only takes in String object inputs for task deadlines/timelines.

This significantly limiits future scope, utility, and further operations with task entries.

Let's implement date and time handling within tasks by merging the changes made in the 'branch-Level-8' branch to 'master'.

commitResults.messageTitle: Ui and MayoBot: Add Ui class & simplify program logic
commitResults.messageBody:
The main code for the bot exists in the main() method for the MayoBot program, with direct UI outputs and messy program logic. As of now, separate classes for Storage, Parser, Commands and TaskList exist.

In order to simplify code readability and adherence to OOP principles, extracting out closely related code as classes is necessary. One important functionality of the bot that needs to be extracted out into a class is UI.

Let's extract out all UI related methods into a separate Ui class, and improve the organization of the MayoBot main file by adding private attributes, consstructors, and a run() method that is called in the main() method.

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge branch 'branch-A-MoreOOP'
Command class: Display messages through Ui class
commitResults.messageBody:
When printing message to console, the Command.execute() method directly calls System.out.println() instead of working through the Ui class.

This violates separation of tasks and responsibilities rule in the code.

Let's add the showMessage() method to the Ui class and make it so that all messages triggered by Commands are printed to the ui through the Ui class.

commitResults.messageTitle: Continue organizing classes into packages
commitResults.messageBody: Let's refactor the code in acvcordance to newly created packages.

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge branch 'branch-A-Packages'
commitResults.messageBody:
All files are currently under a singular directory. Only the exception-related classes are categorized under the mayoBot-exceptions directory.

This leads to class files being disorganized.

Let's organize the classes into suitable java packages and refactor the code accordingly.

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge branch 'add-gradle-support'
commitResults.messageBody: Adding graddle support to the MayoBot project, to automate project builds using Gradle.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add JUnit tests for MayoBot core classes
commitResults.messageBody:
The chatbot project relies on text input/output tests instead of relying on a more sophisticated test suite.

This limits the variety and complexity of tests that can be run for MayoBot.

Let's begin to add JUnit tests for the entire project by createst unit tests for the MayoBot core classes: MayoBot, Command, Parser, Storage, and Ui.

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge branch 'branch-A-JUnit'
commitResults.messageBody: Let's begin to add JUnit tests to test te behaviour of the code.

commitResults.messageTitle: Edit build.gradle to support JAR releases
commitResults.messageBody: Let's edit build.gradle to allow packaging the app as a JAR file.

commitResults.messageTitle: Parser.java: Add JavaDoc comments for class
commitResults.messageBody:
The project does not have JavaDoc comments for non-private classes and methods.

Adding JavaDoc comments will help improve documentation for the MayoBot chatbot project.

Let's start by adding JavaDoc comments to the Parser class.

commitResults.messageTitle: Storage, Ui, Command: Add JavaDoc comments
commitResults.messageBody:
The chatbot code only has JavaDoc comments for the Parser class.

In line with the goal of improving JavaDoc documentation, we need to add these comments for the rest of the core function classes.

Let's continue this task by adding JavaDoc comments for Sotrage, Parser and Ui classes and their methods.

commitResults.messageTitle: MayoBot and Task classes: Add JavaDoc comments
commitResults.messageBody:
The project does not have JavaDoc comments for the main MayoBot class and all Task-related classes (inclduing TaskList).

As part of the goal of adding JavaDoc documentation, these comments have to be added to the rest of the classes involved in this project.

Let's do so by adding JavaDoc comments to the following classes: MayoBot, Task, TaskList, TodoTask, DeadlineTask, and EventTask.

commitResults.messageTitle: Command: Tweak to fit coding standard
commitResults.messageBody:
The indentation for the switch case blocks in the Command#execute method do not follow the given Java coding standard.

We need to fix the indentation to adhere to the coding standard.

Let's fix the indentation in the switch case block in the specified method.

commitResults.messageTitle: Command and TaskList: Add "find" command
commitResults.messageBody:
The user cannot search for existing tasks in the saved TaskList.

Adding a "find" command for the user to find a task by searching for a keyword in the task description would improve utility of the chatbot.

Let's add the find command by adding the necessary methods and changes to the TaskList and Command class.

commitResults.messageTitle: Command and TaskList: Separate ui updates from findTask method
commitResults.messageBody:
The findTask method in TaskList prints out corresponding output directly to the interface from the method itself.

To maintain separation of tasks, updates and output to UI should be through the Ui class.

Let's fix this within the "find" command implementation and the printTask/printTasks methods in TaskList by ensuring that outputs are displayed through the Ui class.

To make this change for Command#findTask, changes need to be made to Command#execute as well in the switch/case block for case "find".

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge branch 'branch-A-JavaDoc'
commitResults.messageBody:
The chatbot project code has no JavaDoc comments for any methods or classes.

Adding JavaDoc comments for at least some non-private classes/methods greatly improves documentation.

Let's start by adding JavaDoc comments for more than half of all non-private classes and methods.

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge branch 'branch-A-CodingStandard'
commitResults.messageBody:
Some parts of the chatbot project do not adhere to the Java coding standard specified for the project.

It is imperative the project follows this standard to ensure consistency with the project guidelines.

Let's fix the coding standard in files, classes, and methods where it failed to do so.

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge branch 'branch-Level-9'
commitResults.messageBody:
The chatbot does not have any function to search for listed tasks.

Adding a find command would give users a way to find a task by searching for a keyword in the task description.

Let's add the implemntation for a find command by making changes to the Command and TaskList files.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add Checkstyle config files
commitResults.messageBody:
The MayoBot project does not use checkStyle to check coding style violations.

Adding checkSyle would help with adhering to coding stamdards. In order to implement this, the necessary configuration files need to be added.

Let's add checkstyle.xml and suppressions.xml to the ./config/checkstyle/ directory.

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix checkStyle violations
commitResults.messageBody:
After adding checkStyle to the project, running the gradle tasks checkstyleMain and checkstyleTest bring multiple coding standard violations.

It is important to take note of these results and make changes accordingly.

Let's fix most of the coding standard violations in the project across the main and test files.

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge branch 'branch-A-CheckStyle'
commitResults.messageBody:
The project does not use checkStyle to check for coding standard violations.

Adding checkStyle would significantly help find coding standard violations and help fix them.

Let's add and use checkStyle with Gradle to detect coding standrad violations.
